item.title: levure de bi√®re #5.3: Tropical buckwheat dream
item.description: An audacious Buchweizenbrot (46.88% caramel buckwheat malt + 46.88% ancient grains + 6.25% pale barley malt). Mixed-fermentations with Escarpment Labs' traditional Latvian KolnasƒÅta, Berkeley Yeast’s GM thiolized London Tropics, and Imperial Yeast’s Suburban Brett. Boldly earth, charmingly fruity, and deeply satisfying.
item.content:
Beer = liquid bread. Want to stay updated on my craft beer yeast bread-plays? Subscribe to the newsletter!

I’m surprised how many people watch only HBO and whatever the Netflix algorithm recommends. It’s kind of like the folks who email me asking factual questions – have they never heard of the internet? There’s a vast cornucopia of streaming series out there; if you pick the right one, your life will be enhanced.

Last night I watched the final two episodes of “Farzi” while licking a plate of buttery pav bhaji. When the show was over, I spontaneously exclaimed, “That was great!”

Frankly, not as great as “Le Bureau des L√©gendes” or “Poƒçivali u miru”, but really fulfilling. And it’s hard to find those shows these days.

“Farzi” is about the rigid caste system in India, where upward mobility is extremely limited. But that doesn’t mean you can’t dream. Opportunities are closed. But that doesn’t mean you’re not smart or willful.

Most people are so addicted to brands (e.g. HBO or Apple TV+). They watch only light stuff like comedy; they say real life is daunting enough, they don’t want to be brought down by a show.

That’s what life is all about: new experiences, stretching your horizons, because otherwise you’d end up living on repeats, waiting to die.

Which is why I’ve been experimenting with uncommon grains.

Wheat has been the hegemony in the bread world, while barley reigns supreme in the brewing industry. Malt has become synonymous with barley the way that flour has with wheat, but malt can be made from any type of (pseudo)grain.

Buckwheat

The only exposure most people in the West have to buckwheat is in pancakes, which is quite sad.

Buckwheat (Fagopyrum sagittatum syn. F. esculentum) is a curious and misunderstood food. It’s not a “wheat”, but is treated like one. It’s actually a shrub, related to rhubarb; it produces seeds on the flower heads. These seeds (or kernels) are what get ground into flour.

Like other seeds, buckwheat is high in both protein (18% by weight!) and fiber, but it’s unique among the seeds we typically eat, because it’s mainly composed of carbs, with lower fat and higher starch content than, say, sunflower seeds or chia seeds. IMO, buckwheat has a well-balanced starch, protein, fat, and mineral composition, and is absolutely delicious. Hands-down one of my favorite “cereals.”

Buckwheat was long thought to have originated in central Asia, somewhere between Lake Baikal and Manchuria. Recent research now leans toward southwest China and the Himalayan region as the center of origin. The two cultivated species of buckwheat, Fagopyrum esculentum (common buckwheat) and Fagopyrum tataricum (tartary buckwheat) are Chinese domesticates, presumably originating in upland southwest China, outside the major rice and millet centers.

Buckwheat is known as grano saraceno in Italian and sarrasin in French, leading the late food writer Waverly Root to assume that buckwheat originated in Asia Minor and was introduced by either the Turks, the Crusaders, and/or the Moors to places in Europe where other grains didn’t grow well and where the people ate “robustly” – such as Brittany, Finland, Styria, central France and the Tyrolian Alps. Europeans of the Middle Ages, however, used the term “saracen” to describe many things that simply came from the East, whether they were Arabian or not.

According to the contemporary Italian botanist Valerio Giacomini, who has made a thorough study of buckwheat, there are three possible ways buckwheat arrived in Europe:

  • through southern Russia, Poland, and Germany –> Belgium and France;
  • through Turkey –> Greece, Hungary, and southern Russia; and
  • through the maritime contacts of Venice, which might explain in part the ascription of “saracen.”

There is a legend that Joos van Ghistele brought it back with him from his journey to the Holy Land in 1485. Who knows. In any case, the origin of buckwheat is unknown, even if its name in Latin languages suggests an Arab provenance. The plant’s English name, “buckwheat”, came from the Dutch word for “beech” (boec) and wheat, because it can be used in food, like wheat.

What seems certain, though, is that buckwheat has been a traditional food around the world, particularly in regions with short growing seasons and poor soil. Eastern Europeans eat a porridge of toasted buckwheat groats (kasha). In the mountainous valley of Lombardy, Italy, a traditional winter dish is pizzoccheri, basically short buckwheat pasta tossed with butter, cabbage, cheese, garlic, and sage – a poor “peasant” tradition.

Buckwheat has a rich history in the United States as well, unlike other ancient grains. It was common during the Colonial era, but began to decline in popularity after the Civil War ended.

Malted buckwheat

I had the good fortune of experimenting with some caramel buckwheat malt from Grouse Malt House, a dedicated gluten-free craft malthouse in Wellington, Colorado. (I was not looking for gluten-free alternatives per se, but rather malts made from uncommon grains. Grouse has been crafting a ton of those since ~2013.)

The dark, triangular-shaped hulls covering the buckwheat seeds are left on, to help brewers lauter/filter more easily. The hull is very tough, but is edible when ground and provides a good source of fiber. Even after soaking and boiling, though, unhulled buckwheat is too chewy and too earthy for most people’s palates.

This malt, out of the box, smelled like a forest right after a rain.

Buckwheat can be milled with or without the hull. The traditional method is milling with the hulls. And yes, some millers even add extra hulls. Flour ground from unhulled buckwheat will be greyish, with tiny black specks – it looks darker and tastes a tad stronger than flour made from hulled buckwheat (groats).

When freshly ground, this caramel buckwheat malt has an unmistakable earthy aroma – it creates a woodsy vibe that’s bold but not overly aggressive, evoking mental imagery of a deep, verdant forest. There’s also a little sunflower seed-like nutty aroma. It tastes predominantly earthy – like unmalted buckwheat or yellow split peas – with a hint of malty sweetness. Just how I like my buckwheat, despite the lack of a quintessential “caramel” malt vibe.

Many Westerners don’t like that robust flavor of unhulled buckwheat. So there’s a large market for buckwheat flour sans the hulls.

I know pretty well how buckwheat performs and tastes in food, but in beer? I’m not so sure. Enzymatic activities are found to be low in pale buckwheat malt. I would probably agree with what this brewer said about buckwheat:

I suspect that you will be disappointed with the flavor and diastatic power of pale-malt buckwheat, though. If my experience with Colorado Malting Company’s buckwheat malt is any indicator, about the only way to coax any flavor out of it is to make crystal malt; but even that doesn’t do much, considering very little saccharification takes place during the crystal-making process so you don’t get much in the way of caramelized sugars. The only use I have for buckwheat in my beers is unmalted as an adjunct to improve head retention (the malted stuff doesn’t do as well in that regard due to changes in protein contents), or else roasted really dark, as a stand-in for Briess “Midnight Wheat” to impart a smooth roast character to darker beers.

Which is why I picked “caramel” buckwheat malt, not the other two buckwheat options (BK1001 pale and BK1100 roasted) offered by Grouse.

Caramel malt is typically made from “green malt” (wet germinated malt) or rehydrated base malt, mashed at 140-160¬∞F so that the amylase in each individual grain kernel degrades the starch within into simple sugars, and subsequently dried out at >=170¬∞F, which causes the sugars inside the malt to crystallize. It also causes the sugars and nitrogen-based compounds (mostly amino acids and proteins) to combine to form melanoidins. The major variable in the process is the kilning temperature, which determines the depth of the color and the degree of caramelization. The higher the drying temperature, the darker the color will be.

During roasting, most (if not all) of the enzymes in the malt become denatured, and many of the sugars in the malt become caramelized and thus unfermentable, which is why caramel malt is usually used (like an adjunct) to add sweetness and body to the finished beer, instead of as a base malt.

Buckwheat mash

In “caramel” malts made from common grains like barley and wheat, the starch is already gelatinized and saccharified in the core. Malted buckwheat gelatinizes at a temperature that is higher than that at which the amylase becomes denatured. To get any significant fermentables out of buckwheat, a decoction mash or exogenous enzymes may be necessary. Andrew Lavery has some good info on mashing gluten-free grains.

Total dry malts: 80g

ingredient % weight
pale barley malt (Genie - Gallatin Valley Malt) 50% 40g
caramel buckwheat malt (Grouse Malt House) 50% 40g
water 125% 100g

Total: 180g

I mixed everything together and did a triple-decoction mash starting at 95¬∞F:

  • 30 minutes at 95¬∞F
  • 1 hour at ~113¬∞F
  • 1 hour at ~130¬∞F (decocted 1/3 at the end; boiled for 5 minutes)
  • 3 hours at ~150¬∞F (decocted 1/3 at the end; and boiled for 5 minutes)
  • 1 hour at ~160¬∞F (decocted 1/3 at the end; boiled for 5 minutes)
  • 1 hour at ~170¬∞F

The buckwheat malt soaks up water like a sponge, so this mash turned out very thick. It smelled mildly sweet and smoky, reminiscent of toasted sesame seeds. Not at all what you’d expect with a typical “caramel” malt made from barley or wheat.

After saccharification, the mash tasted sweet-ish and boldly buckwheaty.

Buckwheat barm

A lot of people consider the flavor of buckwheat to be in the same general category as rye, but far more rustic, earthy, and flavorful than any of the routinely used grains. Part of that character derives from buckwheat’s caprylic acid content. Caprylic acid (octanoic acid) is a medium-chain fatty acid that is naturally found in palm oil, coconut oil, and milk. It’s a part of medium-chain triglyceride (MCT) products, and believed to have potent antibacterial, antifungal, and anti-inflammatory properties. FYI, capr- comes from Latin capra, meaning “goat”; a lot of people say buckwheat adds a load of “goaty” flavor, which I disagree with.

One great thing about some “off”-tasting fatty acids is that they provide appealing aromas after Brettanomyces combines them with a molecule of ethanol to form an ester. Buckwheat has been researched for its possible caprylic acid contribution to Brettanomyces fermentation, during which the Brett might convert these fatty acid precursors to create ethyl caprylate, an ester often described as sweet, waxy, floral, fruity, pineapple, and wine.

Stage 1: KolnasƒÅta

ingredient % weight
saccharified mash 100% 180g
KolnasƒÅta liquid yeast (Escarpment Labs) 0.5% 1g

Total: 181g

I added 1g of liquid KolnasƒÅta, a continental European farmhouse ale yeast sourced from Bƒìrzpils, Latvia by Escarpment Labs.

KolnasƒÅta is traditionally used to brew beers at home in Latgale (aka. the land of blue lakes), a historical region in eastern Latvia. The brewing usually takes place in wooden tuns, and calls for locally-grown barley malt that’s dried in a smoke sauna.

This yeast is expected to produce “ample doses of pineapple esters along with medium attenuation and flocculation.” I thought this profile would pair well with the other yeasts I was going to add to the barm later on.

Escarpment’s recommended temperature range for KolnasƒÅta is 68-86¬∞F, so I let the inoculated mash (aka. barm) ferment, loosely covered, at 80-84¬∞F for 12 hours. The barm began to show signs of fermentation and exude a subtle fruity aroma like peach and pineapple.

Stage 2: London Tropics

ingredient % weight
stage 1 barm 100% 181g
London Tropics (Berkeley Yeast) 0.5% 0.9g

Total: 181.9g

Next, I added 0.9g of London Tropics from Berkeley Yeast. This London ale yeast-derived thiolized strain produced a POG bomb in a previous experiment, and I’d like to tone down the thiol level this time to see how the final bread might turn out.

Berkeley’s recommended temperature range for London Tropics is 64-72¬∞F. I let the barm ferment at 66-70¬∞F for 24 hours. By the end, the thick mash had nearly risen by 50%-70% and felt fluffy. It smelled much more fruity, pleasantly balanced between guava and pineapple.

Stage 3: Brettanomyces

I intended to add 2g of Brettanomyces bruxellensis. Due to a squirting accident with the homebrew pouch, I ended up adding 6g of the liquid yeast. The 6% inoculation rate was not intentional, but it is what it is.

ingredient % weight
stage 2 barm 100% 181.9g
Suburban Brett (Imperial Yeast) 3.3% 6g

Total: 187.9g

I let this barm sit in my fermentation fridge (set to ~45¬∞F) for 4 days. The barm puffed up like my Italian lievito madre, and developed a more complex aroma that was very pleasing, but hard to put into words.

Buckwheat soaker

I thought another way to get the best flavor out of buckwheat is to cold-soak it for 12+ hours. Let hydrolysis do all the work.

ingredient % weight
caramel buckwheat malt (Grouse Malt House) 92.9% 260g
golden flax seeds, whole 7.1% 20g
water (room temperature) 120% 336g
sea salt 1% 2.8g

Total: 618.8g

After mixing everything together, I let the stiff paste rest, covered, at room temperature for 2 hours; then I moved it into the fridge (~38¬∞F) and left it there until needed.

Final dough

Total flours: 300g (100%)

ingredient % weight
einkorn flour, 100% extraction 65% 195g
Asturian spelt flour, 100% extraction 20% 60g
Ethiopian Blue Tinge emmer flour, 100% extraction 15% 45g
water (room temperature) 73.3% 220g
buckwheat soaker 206.3% 618.8g
buckwheat barm 62.7% 187.9g
sea salt 1% 3g

Total: 1,329.7g (100% extraction = whole grain)

I mixed all ingredients together into a supple and sticky dough.

  • bulk fermentation: 2 hours at ~70¬∞F (the dough started to ferment so fast that I had to slow it down by chilling it) + 14 hours at ~45¬∞F

  • final proof: 3 hours at ~70¬∞F

  • bake: 45 minutes in total; 10 minutes at 400¬∞F and 35 minutes at 350¬∞F.

I was delightfully surprised by how much the bread rose during fermentation and baking.

The bread had a pleasant fruity fragrance, far less overpowering than in my first experiment. I detected some tantalizing notes of pineapple with a hint of lemon. The subtle tropical complexity and breezy tiki vibe complemented the toasty, earthy aroma of buckwheat quite nicely.

Flavor-wise, it was predominantly earthy buckwheat (reminding me of toasted black sesame seeds), with a charming malty character and mildly fruity undertone. I liked it, a lot. While biting into it, I pictured myself in a hammock swaying on a sun-soaked island in the Black Sea.

If you grew up poor like me and got used to eating “peasant food” like galettes de sarrasin, kissel, inaka soba, etc., then you’ll most likely find the deep and earthy flavor of unhulled buckwheat satisfying and nourishing. Otherwise, it’s probably an acquired taste.

I guess quartering thiol levels in this bread worked out well. Once again, more isn’t (always) better. It’s all about understanding what you want to achieve and how your yeast will behave. Recipes are very overrated.

üçªüçªüçªüçª

Special thanks to Richard Preiss (Escarpment Labs) for offering me the opportunity to experiment with unique yeasts.

item.title: levure de bi√®re #3: Lactobacillus + Kveiks + Brettanomyces
item.description: Berliner Weisse reincarnated as a wholegrain bread. A mightily aromatic and tasty scald with craft malts. Sequential mixed-fermentation with cultures from Imperial Yeast: A44 Kveiking, W25 Lacto Brevis, and W15 Suburban Brett.
item.content:
Beer = liquid bread. Want to stay updated on my craft beer yeast bread-plays? Subscribe to the newsletter!

One of my all-time favorite beer styles is Berliner Weisse (German: Berliner Wei√üe), a deliciously tart wheat beer that originated in the region around Berlin, Germany and developed gradually from the 17th to the 20th century. A popular story has it that in 1809, Napoleon and his troops celebrated their Prussian victory with Berliner Weisse; the soldiers described the beer as sweet and tart, strong and effervescent, and dubbed it “the Champagne of the North."1

Berliner Weisse is defined by its mouth-watering sour tang – slightly less sour than a gueuze, and not as funky or vinous. A great Berliner Weisse is complex but straightforward, acidic but infinitely enjoyable. It’s malty but dry, crisp, refreshing, and light – rarely with oakiness, hoppiness, tannins, or acetic flavors.

Whereas weissbier makes the drinker monosyllabic, reserved, and retiring, the Bavarian brewings open his heart and let loose his tongue.

  • Henry Vizetelly

The origins of Berliner Weisse are hazy at best. Along with its sour cousin, Leipziger gose, the wheat ale hearkens back to a time when brewers in northern Germany lived by their own rules. Literally. The area evaded the Bavarian “beer purity” laws known as Reinheitsgebot for centuries, allowing brewers to create funky, sour ales that resemble Belgian styles more than those of the Rhineland.

Weisse in German means “wheat”, and weissbier is usually translated into English as “wheat beer”, which includes a faulty assumption that there is usually a heavy component of wheat in the malt bill. Like the famous witbiers (“white beers”) of Belgium, weisse also means “white.” That is, Berliner Weisse is traditionally brewed from air-dried rather than kiln-dried malt.

There are several competing theories surrounding the development of the style. One theory holds that the French Huguenot refugees, who fled to Berlin in the 17th and early 18th centuries, developed the beer after migrating through Flanders and picking up techniques from brewers of Flanders brown and red ales. There is little hard evidence supporting this theory, although the Landr√© family, who were prominent weissbier brewers and had factories at Stralauer Stra√üe 36/37 and M√ºnzstra√üe 3, were French-born Huguenots. But the Landr√©s didn’t come to Berlin until the second half of the 18th century, and Charles Fr√©deric Edouard Landr√© didn’t acquire the wheat beer brewery at Stralauer Stra√üe 36/37, which was founded in 1780, until 1835. It seems rather late, given the brewing of weissbier in northern Germany predates the 1600s.

Another theory points to an improvement of a beer called Halberst√§dter Broihan, a weissbier that was first developed by the brewer Cord Broihan in the 16th century and became incredibly popular across northern Germany for several centuries. A Hanover native, Broihan returned to his homeland in 1526 after a stay in Hamburg, and tried to copy the then-popular Hamburg beer, but failed. So he invented a wheat beer that soon became fashionable. Berlin brewers succeeded in further developing the recipe and brewing a wheat beer that tasted better and was more digestible. The Berlinische Weitzenbier was born; it was praised by the Berlin doctor J. S. Elsholz as early as 1642. It was officially mentioned for the first time in a 1680 document.

The Bohemian military leader and statesman Albrecht von Wallenstein reportedly appreciated the white beer. However, during the turmoil of the Thirty Years' War (1618-1648), wheat was in short supply. The situation in the Mark Brandenburg was so dire that Wallenstein complained bitterly in a letter to his subordinate Arnim von Boitzenburg, “…dahero denn nicht wei√ü, wie den Durst l√∂schen muss, dieweil ich das Gerstenbier nicht trinken kann…” (”…so I don’t know how to quench my thirst, since I can’t drink the barley beer…")

19th-century Berliners no longer had this problem. By the late 18th century, Berliner Weisse seemed to have emerged as a distinct style of its own, and became available at all times and practically everywhere. Specialty weissbier breweries such as Landr√© on Stralauer Stra√üe, Breithaupt on Palisadenstra√üe, and Willner in Pankow brewed excellent beer.

From the late 1850s to 1870s, however, Berliner Weisse fell out of favor – so much so that an English publisher named Henry Vizetelly predicted in 1859, “Ten years hence and guide-books will describe [weissbier] with the same reverence as the Colosseum in Rome, or the Palace of the Doges in Venice. Ten years later there will be a case in the Berlin Museum containing the mysterious goblets, representing a ‘white or a half white,’ and the so-called ‘cool blonde.'"2

A revival did ensue. In 1879, Vizetelly paid homage to the “k√ºhle blonde” in Berlin Under the New Empire, describing in detail its place in a Berliner’s life.

In front of everyone stood a gigantic tumbler which could have been fitted with ease upon any ordinary head, and which contained a liquid pale and clear as Rhine wine, surmounted by a huge crown of froth not unlike a prize cauliflower. This was the famous “weiss,” the mere mention of which suffices to send a Berliner into raptures and into the mysteries of which I was about to be initiated. … [Berlin was] the city where the k√ºhle blonde is obtained in the greatest perfection and where bier-stuben offering no other beverage to their frequenters abound. The beer is drunk by preference when it is of a certain age, and in perfection it should be largely impregnated with carbonic acid gas and have acquired a peculiar sharp, dry, and by no means disagreeable flavor.

The modern Berliner Weisse developed relatively late, towards the end of the 19th century. Shortly after the turn of the 20th century, wei√übier-stuben (wheat beer bars) mushroomed all over Berlin. At the height of its popularity, Berliner Weisse was the most popular alcoholic drink in Berlin, with dozens of breweries producing it.

History suggests that wheat beers brewed around Berlin were not originally sour (i.e. not any different from those brewed in Hamburg or N√ºrnberg), but rather light and easy to drink compared to the heavier braunbier (brown beer). Most of the weissbiers were about 3% ABV and used a mash of at least 50% wheat. Interestingly, the wort was not boiled and the amount of hops used was minimal. The hops were typically not added in the kettle, but blended into the mash as a separate boiled infusion to increase the mash temperature.

Since the wort wasn’t sterilized, you can easily imagine the enormous diversity of microorganisms that survived into the cooled wort. Thus, it was crucial to start the fermentation as quickly as possible to suppress most of the spoilage microorganisms. Even so, heat-tolerant lactic acid bacteria (LAB) survived and synergistically fermented the worts into beers with a dry and lightly acidic character. This was not true spontaneous fermentation as carried out in lambics – yeast was pitched, but carried both yeast and bacteria from previous fermentations.

A. F. Zimmermann wrote in Der Bier-Brauer als Meister in seinem Fache (1842), “all wheat beers, especially in the summer, easily turn sour and sometimes even sour during the brewing process.”

Other microorganisms survived wort production, too; malts have plenty of their own LAB, for instance. Fermentation took place in wood, which is porous and thus difficult to sanitize.

Therefore, there are 3 production stages where acidification could have taken place:

  1. During mashing: if the mash stood too long, especially at room temperatures

  2. During fermentation: primarily caused by yeast cross-contaminations

  3. During storage: mainly caused by microflora in the storage vessels

The result was a range of beers with vastly differing levels of acidity. Although acidity was not uncommon in beers of the 17th-18th centuries, the variability of the beer meant that it often failed to meet consumers’ expectations.

Both J. G. Kr√ºnitz (in Oekonomische Encyklop√§die, published in 1773) and Johann Samuel Halle3 described the brewing process used in the second half of the 18th century, both indicating production was brewery-specific. For example, Halle offered a recipe made with equal parts of barley and wheat malts, while Kr√ºnitz provided one with 2/3 wheat and 1/3 barley. Such differences continued until only two breweries made the beer at the beginning of the 21st century – and until they merged, Berliner Kindl and Schultheiss followed very different brewing processes.

Kr√ºnitz also wrote about how some of the distinctive features of the style’s brewing methods had already appeared by the 1770s:

  1. A decoction method, in which Berlin brewers pulled off the thinnest portion of a mash from the top, brought it to a boil, and then added hops to the decoction. The remaining wort was never boiled. This was an important technique. LAB is very sensitive to hops and could easily be killed by over-hopping. This is not a problem – in fact, a blessing – when brewing most styles. But Berliner Weisse relies on lactobacilli to acquire its trademark sour note. Over the years, brewers have used several techniques to get around this problem. To this day, the brewers of Berliner Kindl Weisse split the wort, leave half raw, and add hops to only the other half.

  2. Some of the wort was drawn off before cooling and pitched with yeast. By the time the rest of the wort had cooled, this yeasted portion would already be fermenting, and pitched into the main body of wort.

Franz Sch√∂nfeld pointed out in his 1902 book, Die Herstellung oberg√§hriger Biere:

  • In the early decades of the 19th century, Berlin Weissbier brewers regularly refreshed their yeast with fresh Bitterbier yeast brought in from Cottbus. If they kept re-pitching harvested yeast, their beer would get too sour.
  • Only in the 1830s or 1840s did brewers begin using mixed cultures that could be safely re-pitched without needing to be periodically refreshed.

After World War II, the style started to wane again. Even though it’s protected under appellation d’origine contr√¥l√©e (AOC) within Europe – no beer produced outside Berlin can carry the name – Berliner Weisse no longer enjoys the popularity that it once did in its home city. The Berlin tradition has sadly slipped through the cracks and remained in a very mournful state, hanging on by a thin thread.

The consolidated Berliner-Kindl-Schultheiss-Brauerei (now part of the massive Radeberger Gruppe), the last brewery in Berlin producing Berliner Weisse, and therefore the last brewery on Earth that may use the appellation, does not even feature the historic beer during its brewery tours. The ubiquitous brand it produces, Berliner Kindl Weisse, has such a sharp, one-dimensional, lactic sourness that it’s hard to drink without those colorful sugar syrups.

The few commercial breweries that still produce Berliner Weisse no longer use a yeast/bacterial blend to co-ferment the beer; the bacterial fermentation is conducted separately from the yeast fermentation, and the beer is blended to achieve a pre-defined acidity. Beers produced this way are very pale, slightly hazy, and effervescent, with a light tang. They are refreshing oddities, but show little complexity.

Like any beer style that has been around for more than 5 minutes, Berliner Weisse has gone through several transformations, adapting to technological, political and social changes along the way.

One of my biggest qualms about beers labeled as Berliner Weisse on the market is that they are often too light and not sour enough for me. I’d like to amp up the flavor.

Here’s my journey of making a Berliner Weisse-inspired bread from scratch, in the melting pot that is America.

Size: one 9” x 4" loaf

Scald (2h @ 100-105¬∞F, 2h @ 109-114¬∞F, 4h @ 150-155¬∞F)

These days, everyone tells you that Berliner Weisse is brewed with 50% wheat malt and 50% pilsener malt.

From the beginning, Berlin’s brewers sought to keep the beer as white as possible, and used air-dried or lightly kilned wheat. The grist varied throughout history:

  • 75% smoked wheat + 25% lager in 1834
  • 83.3% wheat + 16.7% barley in 1842
  • 87.5% wheat + 12.5% barley in 1845
  • 75% wheat + 25% lager in 1907

Benedikt Koch has an interesting recipe for a historically accurate version; it uses 70% wheat malt and 30% pilsner malt to create “enough mouthfeel and doughiness from the wheat.”

My focus wasn’t on historic accuracy, but on how to play yeasts, bacteria, and grains off each other to create a balanced, tasty bread that has a similar flavor profile to Berliner Weisse.

Total dry malts: 200g

ingredient baker’s % weight
√ñlandsvete wheat malt (Root Shoot Malting, Colorado) 70% 140g
diastatic barley malt4(sun-dried Chevallier) 20% 40g
honey malt (Root Shoot Malting, Colorado) 5% 10g
rye malt (Root Shoot Malting, Colorado) 5% 10g
boiled water (from cooking pasta), cooled off to ~120¬∞F 140% 280g

Process

  1. Grind the malts, individually or collectively, into a flour. It doesn’t have to be super fine.

  2. Place all the malt flours in a bowl or small saucepan; pour the hot pasta water (aka. liquid gold) in 2-3 increments, stirring constantly. It should have the consistency of a slightly thick porridge.

  3. Hold the mash at

    • 100-105¬∞F for 2 hour (to help phytase break down phytin molecules and release phytic acid which lowers the mash pH);
    • 109-114¬∞F for 2 hours (to help maximize the release of ferulic acid, which is a precursor to 4-vinyl-guaiacol, a molecule that’s credited with giving off a clove-like aroma);
    • raise the temperature to 150-155¬∞F and hold for 4 hours (to saccharify).

The mash tasted mightily malty and sweet after 8 hours.

Total: 480g (to be split into 400g and 80g)

Thermophilic sour: Lactobacillus brevis (24h @ 100-95¬∞F)

Breweries are split between their methods in souring Berliner Weisse. On one side, there are kettle-soured proponents; on the other, you have the staunch traditionalists.

Kettle souring allows for a quick turn-around and eliminates a brewery’s concern for cross-contamination. Souring bacteria need a special cleaning procedure, so some brewers prefer the kettle sour technique to lower this risk. Most American breweries use this technique for brewing Berliner Weisse, because it’s fast, simple, and consistent.

The traditional brewing method is to co-ferment with lactobacilli and yeast to make a more expressive flavor profile. This takes longer and requires dedicated sour beer fermenters.

I do what works for me in my home lab. And I’m going to combine the method that Kr√ºnitz mentioned in his 1773 book with Otto Francke’s method of souring patented in 1908.

Important Question for Breweries which produce Acid Beers of the Type of Berlin “Weiss” Beer. O. Francke (Wochensch. Brau., 1907, 24, 621-624). ‚Äî “Weiss” beer is prepared by fermenting wort with yeast and lactic acid bacteria. It is a very difficult matter, however, to acclimatise a mixture of lactic acid bacteria and pure yeast in constant proportions. The author recommends a process (which has been employed for two years with very satisfactory results) in which the lactic acid and yeast fermentations are carried out separately. The wort, as it runs off from the spent grains, is subjected to the action of pure culture lactic acid bacteria until the required degree of acidity is attained. The wort is then boiled, cooled, and fermented with pure culture yeast. The beer thus prepared has a pleasant acid taste, and does not require the aid of certain non-slime forming pediococci (see this Journal, 1907, 13, 626-630) to impart a pleasant flavour to it. If a mature, vinous “Weiss” beer is required, it is only necessary to treat the lactic acid-containing wort with ordinary bacteria-containing “Weiss” beer yeast. The presence of the lactic acid protects the fermenting wort against the attack of dangerous pediococci, and the beer acquires a sound, vinous taste. The beer prepared by the first method (i.e., that in which the lactic acid fermentation is followed by a pure yeast fermentation) only requires a short period of storage before it is ready for consumption. For the lactic acidification, the author employs distillery culture lactic acid bacillus Delbr√ºcki, and for the alcoholic fermentation, top-fermentation pure yeast, Race B (high attenuating).

  • Journal of the Institute of Brewing, Volume 14, Issue 2, 1908, pages 196-197

I drew off 80g of the scald and inoculated with yeast (see barm), while souring the rest 400g.

Let the saccharified scald cool off to ~110¬∞F.

saccharified scald 100% 400g
Lacto Brevis (Imperial Yeast, Oregon) 2% 8g

I could let the scald ferment spontaneously over the course of a few days to develop a harmony of lactic acid, like Berliners did a few hundred years ago. But I opted to lacto-ferment the scald with a thermophilic culture, e.g. Lactobacillus delbr√ºckii subsp. bulgaricus, to build a particular aroma and tart-sweet taste. I have a homemade thermophilic starter (containing multiple wild Lactobacillus strains) that easily achieves this goal, or I can take a shortcut by using a Bulgarian yogurt that contains “live and active cultures.” (IIRC, the Poil√¢ne book has a recipe for a 2-day levain that uses yogurt.)

This time, I wanted to try acidifying the scald with a strain of Lactobacillus brevis from Imperial Yeast.

Lacto Brevis is a great strain for souring wort in the kettle or fermenter, prior to adding yeast for fermentation.

I recall reading somewhere that Lactobacillus brevis typically produces more lactic acid than strains like Lactobacillus delbr√ºckii.

Thermophilic cultures love and thrive off heat. Unless you plan to ferment outdoors in the thick of summer in Arizona, you generally need some setup (yogurt maker or crockpot) to keep the heat consistent.

Other LAB strains you could consider, instead of Lactobacillus brevis:

  • Lactobacillus delbr√ºckii: The species name delbr√ºckii came from Max Delbr√ºck, a Berlin native and a founder of microbiology, who characterized bacteria in the sour beers of Berlin in the 1930s.
  • Lactobacillus helveticus: a primary culture used in the manufacturing of hard and extra-hard Italian and Swiss cheeses.
  • Lactobacillus acidophilus
  • Lactobacillus lactis
  • Lactobacillus plantarum
  • Lactobacillus paracasei
  • Streptococcus salivarius subsp. thermophilus
  • Pediococcus pentosaceus

Regardless of which strain you use, any of them, to an extent, has a positive effect on the aroma and taste of the bread.

I added 9.6g of Lacto Brevis to the scald as an inoculation medium, and mixed it in evenly. Then I covered the mixture with a plastic wrap, pressing down to remove as much oxygen as possible. Keep in mind that liquid yeast cultures from different labs have different concentrations; adjust inoculation percentage accordingly.

I typically hold the thermophilic stage at 110-120¬∞F, but Imperial Yeast recommends a temperature range of 100-85¬∞F for Lacto Brevis (White Labs has also shown that Lactobacillus brevis struggles with lactic acid production at >107¬∞F), so I left the scald to sour for 24 hours at 100-95¬∞F.

After 24 hours, the scald showed little activity, which is probably a good sign. Pure cultures of Lactobacillus cannot fully ferment wort. If it starts bubbling and producing CO‚ÇÇ visibly, then it’s likely cross-contaminated with yeast. Thomas H√ºbbe, in his 2016 master thesis “effect of mixed cultures on microbiological development in Berliner Weisse”, supports that Lactobacillus attenuates <10% of the sugars in wort.

The scald smelled neutral (no funky, phenolic aroma), and tasted mildly tart and sweet. I thought that was a sweet spot – I didn’t want the thermophilic souring to go too far or have a very low pH that could disrupt the yeast’s fermentation. The scald will develop its maximal character later from other cultures.

Total: 408g

Barm: Kveiks (8h @ 100-95¬∞F)

About 2/3 of the way through the thermophilic sour, I made a barm with a blend of kveik ale yeasts.

ingredient baker’s % weight
saccharified scald 100% 80g

I used Imperial Yeast’s A44 Kveiking, a blend of 3 kveik strains that “thrives in hot fermentations when big complex ester profiles are desired” and “can produce an insane amount of pineapple, guava and other exotic tropical fruit aromas.”

Typically, one would use a neutral German or European ale yeast to ferment a Berliner Weisse, so the resulting flavors won’t contradict each other. But this Kveiking’s ester profile happens to match the tropical tart sweetness of Root Shoot’s honey malt. It would be really nice if the former could accentuate the latter.

The Kveiking blend also works well when fermenting kettle soured worts for a strong tropical fruit character.

As with other kveiks, a little bit goes a long way. A low pitch rate (e.g. on the dangerous edge of underpitching), coupled with a continuously high fermentation temperature, can drive these aromatics even higher.

Kveiking has an attenuation rate of 75-85% and low flocculation. Imperial Yeast recommends a temperature range of 97-75¬∞F for Kveiking. So I mixed in 0.4g of the liquid yeast (adjust the inoculation percentage accordingly based on concentration), gave it a vigorous mix, and let the barm ferment at 100-95¬∞F (same temperatures as Lacto Brevis) for 8 hours.

The barm already doubled in volume after 6 hours. The surface was very bubbly. I stirred it back down, and let it ripen for another 2 hours.

When fully ripe, the barm smelled faintly beery and mildly alcoholic, with some fruity notes. It tasted explosively flavorful, like a pineapple-based tropical fruit punch infused with guava, persimmon, and cinnamon apple!

Maybe the intrigue of Berliner Weisse comes from what the yeast does in an acidic environment: It comes up with some fun cider, sauvignon blanc, passion fruit, funky tropical-ness – which makes this style uber interesting.

Total: 80.4g

Mesophilic sour (3h @ 95-85¬∞F, 3h @ 85-75¬∞F)

Once the barm and the thermophilic sour were both done with their respective fermentation, I proceeded to the mesophilic phase.

Step 1: 3h @ 95-85¬∞F

I dropped 40% (32g) of the ripened barm to the surface of the thermophilic sour, did not mix at all, and just left it to open-ferment at falling temperatures from 95¬∞F to 85¬∞F for 3 hours.

In this temperature range, Lactobacillus brevis continues to work, acidifying the scald further. The barm begins yeast fermentation of the soured scald.

After 2 hours, I began to notice some very active bubbling (CO‚ÇÇ) on the surface where the barm was dropped.

Step 2: 3h @ 85-75¬∞F

After 3 hours, I added the remainder of the barm, gave it a thorough mix, and left it to open-ferment at 85-75¬∞F for another 3 hours.

In this temperature range, yeast fermentation continues. Lactobacillus brevis should show reduced activity or even become dormant in this temperature range.

Total: 488.4g

Complex sour: Brettanomyces bruxellensis (24h @ 70-60¬∞F)

It was not until the second half of the 20th century that brewing scientists identified Brettanomyces in Berliner Weisse. F. J. Methner’s 1987 thesis on Berliner Weisse showed that the mixed pitching cultures contained Brettanomyces and a second variety passed on through brewery equipment. The slow-acting strains affected flavor and aroma only in bottles that were cellared for a long time.

Over the last few years, a number of people (e.g. Richard Preiss of Escarpment Labs) have isolated Berliner Weisse Brettanomyces strains out of old bottles and even kept some of them alive. Brewing with historical strains must be fun!

Funk and Brettanomyces-derived flavors are not required in modern Berliner Weisse. Since I’m a hopeless fan of funk, I had to seek out some Brettanomyces and added a little bit during the tertiary fermentation to accentuate the bread’s complexity. IMO, the main function of Brettanomyces in Berliner Weisse is to transform lactic and acetic acid to ethyl lactate and ethyl acetate.

Keep in mind, though, too much Brettanomyces can throw a Berliner Weisse off balance, and detract from its inherent thirst-quenching character. Great funky beers/breads are balanced and fresh-tasting.

ingredient baker’s % weight
mesophilic sour 100% 488.4g
W15 Suburban Brett (Imperial Yeast, Oregon) 1% 5g

I added 5g (about 1% of total scald weight thus far) of Imperial Yeast’s Suburban Brett to the finished mesophilic sour. This Brettanomyces bruxellensis strain is said to produce “complex and balanced aromas of sour cherry, dried fruit and balanced by a unique tropical fruit profile.”

According to Milk The Funk wiki page on Brettanomyces:

If pitched into a beer that has already been fermented by Saccharomyces or if co-pitched with Saccharomyces, a wider range of flavors including the funkier flavors can be produced by changing some of the flavor compounds produced during the Saccharomyces fermentation into other flavor compounds, although Brettanomyces can also produce funky phenols on its own (de novo) without phenolic precursors produced from Saccharomyces. A small cell count of Brettanomyces is plenty for creating these flavors if pitched after and co-pitched with Saccharomyces, and normally a starter is not necessary unless pitching Brettanomyces as the primary fermenter.

Imperial Yeast recommends a temperature range of 74-64¬∞F for this Brettanomyces bruxellensis strain, so I let it ferment (loosely covered) at 70-60¬∞F for 24 hours.

At these cooler temperatures, kveiks slow down and sit quietly in the background (e.g. lower attenuation and less fruity esters), while Brettanomyces shines.

When done, the mash became incredibly lively. It had an intensely fruity aroma and flavor that reminded me of pineapple, guava, passion fruit, tamarind, and even the Swedish mesophilic yogurt, filmj√∂lk! Not one-dimensionally sour, but deeply tropical with a complex sweet tartness. Unbelievably tasty.

Brettanomyces certainly contributed a different touch of tartness than Lactobacillus brevis; they complemented each other well in this barm. Brettanomyces can be funky / fruity and tart, but not sour.

Total: 493.4g

I prefer my bread to have just a hint of natural sweetness, rather than plenty sweet. Add malt syrup or honey, if desired.

I basically mixed everything together into a smooth, cohesive, and soft dough (adjust hydration as necessary). I let it sit at room temperature (~68¬∞F) for 20 minutes to autolyze, before giving it a few rounds of stretching and folding. The gluten was somewhat weak, but it’s okay.

I fermented the dough at room temperature (~68¬∞F) for 90 minutes. It expanded by ~50% and felt very puffy.

Then I degassed the dough and shaped it into a log (form into a boule or b√¢tard if desired), and placed it in a 9" x 4" loaf pan for final proof.

After another 90 minutes at ~68¬∞F, the dough rose by ~50% and formed a domed surface with a few cracks. I sprayed the dough with water and baked it for 45 minutes in my ghetto toaster oven (first 15 minutes at 375¬∞F; then 30 minutes at 325¬∞F).

After baking, I let the bread cool off and cure for 12 hours before cutting.

Tasting

Who knew a surprise was awaiting me when I sliced into this bread?

The aroma was very interesting and inviting, like a zesty Granny Smith apple with a hint of raisin and cinnamon.

The color of the crumb was somewhere between soft yellow orange and luscious grapefruit (probably due to the bran and germ in unsifted whole red wheat flour).

The texture was comparable to that of my regular sourdough breads. The crust was very thin and crisp; the crumb tight and soft. Mouth-filling, biscuity, and wheaty. Not ethereally fluffy, but still light on the palate.

The flavor was mellow yet deeply layered. It started off with a delicate apple pie; continued to a medley of fruits (banana, orange, raisins, cinnamon apple, strawberries, apricot, peach, lychee, passion fruit…) that somehow reminded me of banana nut muffins or blueberry streusel cakes; and then transitioned perfectly to a mild wheat sweetness with a little slightly clove-ish undertone.

The finish was mildly tangy (reminiscent of pineapple), and a little “dry” after I swallowed. There was a wheaty aftertaste. The touch of smooth, rounded acidity left my mouth watering and wanting another bite. Whole wheat seemed to have played off the tartness that defines Berliner Weisse.

It was subtly tart and well balanced, not unduly sour or puckering. You can tell the nice balance of lactic acid in this bread by its lack of sharp bitterness or a salty-type quality.

Wheat-forward, apple-esque, and unexpectedly nuanced.

Like a Berliner Weisse that’s light, zippy, zingy, and drinkable, this bread was very pleasant to eat on its own.

A little sweet, a little sour, and a whole lot of complex fruity notes. It’s the perfect buddy to soak in that summer social sun with. I’m amazed by the harmonious balance of sweetness and acidity, the marvelous self-conducted symphony by different yeasts and bacteria.

The slices paired exquisitely with raspberry jam and goat cheese for breakfast; with leftover Easter ham (or a hot bratwurst) and some sauerkraut for lunch/dinner.

When toasted, this bread took on a slightly different flavor profile: more subtle, less cinnamony, more fruity. It smelled more like freeze-dried apple slices, fruit punch, and Jolly Rancher; and tasted more like field-fresh apples.

One things for sure – this bread was too easy to enjoy. The whole loaf disappeared in record time (I invited 4 tasters, each of whom gobbled up a few slices; nobody believed this bread had no fruit in it). Simple and elegant, delicious and refreshing. I can see how the mystique of Berliner Weisse has defied convention and beguiled invaders and imbibers for centuries.

I would think this bread tastes best 24 hours after baking.

Post-baking thoughts

I have learned a lot more about yeasts through this experiment. Yeast is going to be the new hops.

Once again, it’s crazy to think that a bread with such complex flavors was made from just some humble grains, without any modern high-tech add-ins.

I should have doubled the recipe and made more than 1 loaf. This is a bread I will definitely make again (it was so worth it, and I could easily adapt the timing to my own WFH schedule). I may even top-crop some cultures from the barm for future batches.

Fruity sweetness

In the 19th century, Germans started to find Berliner Weisse a little too tart and added sweeteners to soften its acidity. Originally, they added k√ºmmel (a caraway-based liqueur), but today it’s common to add a shot of schuss, or syrup, directly to the glass before it’s filled with beer. In Berlin, when you order a Berliner Weisse, the waiter will often ask, “rot oder gr√ºn?” (“red or green?")

The colors refer to the type of syrup you’d like to add to the beer. Red is usually a sweet raspberry syrup known as himbeersirup. Green is a more traditional grassy herbal syrup made from waldmeister (woodruff).

“A great favourite with the ladies is the frothy Berlin white beer, drunk out of large bowl-shaped glass, and with a liqueur-glass of raspberry syrup added to it.”

  • Dundee Evening Telegraph (Wednesday 01 November 1905, page 6)

While Germans commonly add syrups to their Berliner Weisse to balance its funky sourness, Americans put their own twists on the style by adding different combinations of fruits. I don’t think this bread needed any extra fruitiness (it’s not a fruit juice), but I may experiment with adding ~10% of wild pawpaw pur√©e in a future iteration.

Lactobacillus brevis

According to Benedikt Koch’s research, the main Lactobacillus strain found in Berliner Weisse was Lactobacillus brevis. I did not know this at all before making this bread. I used Lacto Brevis because that was what I had on hand at the moment, other than my homemade thermophilic starter. Other hop-tolerant Lactobacillus strains, such as L. lindnerii, L. casei, L. coryniformis and L. plantarum, have also been found in Berliner Weisse.

I found a wealth of information on Lactobacillus brevis in a 2003 paper called “beer spoilage bacteria and hop resistance.”

Additionally, I read that a “symbiosis” between yeast and Lactobacillus only seems to work when the Lactobacillus is L. brevis. This rod-shaped Lactobacillus strain seems to leave the simpler sugars to the yeast, which keeps the yeast somewhat fitter in a hostile, acidic environment. There is little information on how this works in beer literature. In sourdough literature, however, it’s mentioned and researched several times.

Malts and thiols

How much of the bread’s bright, tropical-fruit aromas and flavors are contributed by malts and yeasts, respectively?

Currently, hops high in bound thiols (e.g. Saaz and Calypso) and genetically-modified “thiolized” yeasts are the go-to tools that brewers are employing to maximally unleash previously inaccessible tropical aromas into their beers. However, a few scientists and brewers are discovering malts may be the most powerful player in this realm.
